message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Review of Agent-Based Programming for Multi-Agent Systems
Paper Abstract: Intelligent and autonomous agents is a subarea of symbolic artificial intelligence where these agents decide, either reactively or proactively, upon a course of action by reasoning about the information that is available about the world (including the environment, the agent itself, and other agents). It encompasses a multitude of techniques, such as negotiation protocols, agent simulation, multi-agent argumentation, multi-agent planning, and many others. In this paper, we focus on agent programming and we provide a systematic review of the literature in agent-based programming for multi-agent systems. In particular, we discuss both veteran (still maintained) and novel agent programming languages, their extensions, work on comparing some of these languages, and applications found in the literature that make use of agent programming.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Multi-Agent Planning - Search Results

Here's what I found about multi-agent planning:

### Definition

In computer science multi-agent planning involves coordinating the resources and activities of multiple agents.(no content)Multiagent planning is concerned with planning by (and for) multiple agents and can involve agents planning for a common goal or an agent coordinating the plans.

### Relationship to Other Fields

When there are more than one agent, we have multi-agent planning, which is closely related to game theory.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Multi-Agent Pathfinding

One specific application of multi-agent planning is Multi-Agent Pathfinding (MAPF). The problem of Multi-Agent Pathfinding is an instance of multi-agent planning and consists in the computation of collision-free paths for a group of agents from their location to an assigned target.(no content)It is an optimization problem, since the aim is to find those paths that optimize a given objective function, usually defined as the number of time steps until all agents reach their goal cells.

### Key Considerations

Key questions in multi-agent planning include whether there is only one agent or several agents, whether the agents are cooperative or selfish, and whether all agents construct their own plans separately or if plans are constructed centrally for all agents.

Web search results for query: "Agent programming languages"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-oriented programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_programming"},{"title":"Category:Agent-based programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Agent-based_programming_languages"},{"title":"GOAL agent programming language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GOAL_agent_programming_language"},{"title":"SARL (programming language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARL_(programming_language)"},{"title":"AgentSpeak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AgentSpeak"},{"title":"List of programming languages by type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_programming_languages_by_type"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"List of programming languages for artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_programming_languages_for_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of agent programming languages:

## What are Agent Programming Languages?

Agent-oriented programming allows the developer to build, extend and use software agents, which are abstractions of objects that can message other agents.

## Key Agent Programming Languages

Several specialized languages have been developed for agent programming:

**AgentSpeak**: AgentSpeak is an agent-oriented programming language based on logic programming and the belief–desire–intention software model (BDI) architecture for (cognitive) autonomous agents.(no content)The language is also one of the most popular agent-oriented languages because of the development of the Jason platform.

**GOAL**: GOAL is an agent programming language for programming cognitive agents. GOAL agents derive their choice of action from their beliefs and goals. The language provides the basic building blocks to design and implement cognitive agents by programming constructs that allow and facilitate the manipulation of an agent's beliefs and goals and to structure its decision-making.

**SARL**: SARL is a modular agent-oriented programming language that aims at providing the fundamental abstractions for dealing with concurrency, distribution, interaction, decentralization, reactivity, autonomy and dynamic reconfiguration.

**JADE**: For the Java-platform one of the frameworks is JADE.

**PADE**: PADE is a python package to develop intelligent agents in python language. This framework complies to FIPA and ACL standards.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Intelligent agents artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Virtual intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_intelligence"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"History of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Rational agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_agent"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_education"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about intelligent agents in artificial intelligence:

## Definition

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.(no content)AI textbooks define artificial intelligence as the "study and design of intelligent agents," emphasizing that goal-directed behavior is central to intelligence.

## Key Characteristics

Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex, with a basic thermostat or control system considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria.(no content)Intelligent agents should react to changes in their environment in a timely way, proactively pursue goals, and be flexible and robust (able to handle unexpected situations).

## Types and Applications

A specialized subset of intelligent agents, agentic AI (also known as an AI agent or simply agent), expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.(no content)ChatGPT and the Roomba vacuum are examples of goal-based agents.

## Related Concepts

Intelligent agents are closely related to software agents—autonomous computer programs that carry out tasks on behalf of users. Additionally, related concepts include autonomous agents (capable of modifying the methods of achieving their objectives), distributed agents (being executed on physically distinct computers), and multi-agent systems (distributed agents that work together to achieve an objective).

Links: [{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Virtual intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_intelligence"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Embodied agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embodied_agent"},{"title":"History of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Rational agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_agent"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_education"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about intelligent agents in artificial intelligence:

## Definition

In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.(no content)AI textbooks define artificial intelligence as the "study and design of intelligent agents," emphasizing that goal-directed behavior is central to intelligence.

## Key Characteristics

Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex, with a basic thermostat or control system considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria.(no content)Intelligent agents should react to changes in their environment in a timely way, proactively pursue goals, and be flexible and robust (able to handle unexpected situations).

## Types and Applications

A specialized subset of intelligent agents, agentic AI (also known as an AI agent or simply agent), expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.(no content)ChatGPT and the Roomba vacuum are examples of goal-based agents.

## Related Concepts

Intelligent agents are closely related to software agents—autonomous computer programs that carry out tasks on behalf of users. Additionally, related concepts include autonomous agents (capable of modifying the methods of achieving their objectives), distributed agents (being executed on physically distinct computers), and multi-agent systems (distributed agents that work together to achieve an objective).

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent systems"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"}]

Here are the search results for "Multi-agent systems":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Composition and Characteristics

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents in a multi-agent system have autonomy—agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous—and exhibit decentralization, where no agent is designated as controlling (or the system is effectively reduced to a monolithic system).

## Applications and Recent Developments

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Related Research Areas

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Web search results for query: "Argumentation artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_framework"},{"title":"Argument technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_technology"},{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Logic of argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_of_argumentation"},{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"},{"title":"Existential risk from artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existential_risk_from_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Philosophy of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Argüman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arg%C3%BCman"},{"title":"Katie Atkinson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katie_Atkinson"},{"title":"Araucaria (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Araucaria_(software)"}]

Here are the key findings from the search on "Argumentation artificial intelligence":

## Overview

In artificial intelligence and related fields, an argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments.

## Main Applications and Fields

Argument technology is a sub-field of collective intelligence and artificial intelligence that focuses on applying computational techniques to the creation, identification, analysis, navigation, evaluation and visualisation of arguments and debates.(no content)Efforts have been made within the field of artificial intelligence to perform and analyze argumentation with computers.(no content)Argumentation has been used to provide a proof-theoretic semantics for non-monotonic logic, starting with the influential work of Dung (1995).

## Key Subfields

Several specialized areas have emerged within this domain:

- **Argument Mining**: The goal of argument mining is the automatic extraction and identification of argumentative structures from natural language text with the aid of computer programs.

- **Logic of Argumentation**: The logic of argumentation (LA) is a formalised description of the ways in which humans reason and argue about propositions. It is used, for example, in computer artificial intelligence systems in the fields of medical diagnosis and prognosis.

## Practical Applications

Argument technology can reduce both individual and group biases and facilitate more accurate decisions. Argument-based decision support systems do so by helping users to distinguish between claims and the evidence supporting them, and express their confidence in and evaluate the strength of evidence of competing claims.

Web search results for query: "Negotiation protocols"

Links: [{"title":"Application-Layer Protocol Negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application-Layer_Protocol_Negotiation"},{"title":"Autonegotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonegotiation"},{"title":"Negotiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negotiation"},{"title":"SPNEGO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SPNEGO"},{"title":"Internet Protocol Control Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Protocol_Control_Protocol"},{"title":"Sequential bargaining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequential_bargaining"},{"title":"Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Security_Association_and_Key_Management_Protocol"},{"title":"Noise Protocol Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noise_Protocol_Framework"},{"title":"Port Aggregation Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Aggregation_Protocol"},{"title":"Kerberized Internet Negotiation of Keys - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerberized_Internet_Negotiation_of_Keys"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of negotiation protocols:

## General Negotiation

Negotiation is a dialogue between two or more parties to resolve points of difference, gain an advantage for an individual or collective, or craft outcomes to satisfy various interests.(no content)Sequential bargaining (also known as alternate-moves bargaining, alternating-offers protocol) is a structured form of bargaining between two participants, in which the participants take turns in making offers.

## Technology and Network Protocols

The search results reveal several technical negotiation protocols used in computing and networking:

**ALPN (Application-Layer Protocol Negotiation)**: ALPN is a Transport Layer Security (TLS) extension that allows the application layer to negotiate which protocol should be performed over a secure connection.

**Autonegotiation**: Autonegotiation is a signaling mechanism and procedure used by Ethernet over twisted pair by which two connected devices choose common transmission parameters, such as speed, duplex mode, and flow control.

**SPNEGO**: Simple and Protected GSSAPI Negotiation Mechanism (SPNEGO) is a GSSAPI "pseudo mechanism" used by client-server software to negotiate the choice of security technology, used when a client application wants to authenticate to a remote server, but neither end is sure what authentication protocols the other supports.

**Key Exchange Protocols**: Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP) is a protocol defined by RFC 2408 for establishing security association (SA) and cryptographic keys in an Internet environment.

These protocols serve critical functions in automating and securing communications between computers and networks.

## General Negotiation

Negotiation is a dialogue between two or more parties to resolve points of difference, gain an advantage for an individual or collective, or craft outcomes to satisfy various interests.(no content)Sequential bargaining (also known as alternate-moves bargaining, alternating-offers protocol) is a structured form of bargaining between two participants, in which the participants take turns in making offers.

## Technology and Network Protocols

The search results reveal several technical negotiation protocols used in computing and networking:

**ALPN (Application-Layer Protocol Negotiation)**: ALPN is a Transport Layer Security (TLS) extension that allows the application layer to negotiate which protocol should be performed over a secure connection.

**Autonegotiation**: Autonegotiation is a signaling mechanism and procedure used by Ethernet over twisted pair by which two connected devices choose common transmission parameters, such as speed, duplex mode, and flow control.

**SPNEGO**: Simple and Protected GSSAPI Negotiation Mechanism (SPNEGO) is a GSSAPI "pseudo mechanism" used by client-server software to negotiate the choice of security technology, used when a client application wants to authenticate to a remote server, but neither end is sure what authentication protocols the other supports.

**Key Exchange Protocols**: Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP) is a protocol defined by RFC 2408 for establishing security association (SA) and cryptographic keys in an Internet environment.

Web search results for query: "Symbolic artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Symbolic artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Neuro-symbolic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuro-symbolic_AI"},{"title":"GOFAI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GOFAI"},{"title":"Jacques Pitrat - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Pitrat"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence Markup Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence_Markup_Language"},{"title":"William A. Martin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_A._Martin"},{"title":"Computational cognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_simulation"},{"title":"Outline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Symbolic Artificial Intelligence:

## Definition and Overview

Symbolic artificial intelligence is the term for the collection of all methods in artificial intelligence research that are based on high-level symbolic (human-readable) representations of problems, logic, and search.

## Historical Development

Symbolic AI was the dominant paradigm of AI research from the mid-1950s until the mid-1990s.(no content)Researchers in the 1960s and the 1970s were convinced that symbolic approaches would eventually succeed in creating a machine with artificial general intelligence and considered this the ultimate goal of their field.(no content)An early boom, with early successes such as the Logic Theorist and Samuel's Checkers Playing Program, led to unrealistic expectations and promises and was followed by the first AI Winter as funding dried up.(no content)A second boom (1969–1986) occurred with the rise of expert systems, their promise of capturing corporate expertise, and an enthusiastic corporate embrace.

## Applications and Successes

During the 1960s, symbolic approaches achieved great success at simulating intelligent behavior in structured environments such as game-playing, symbolic mathematics, and theorem-proving.(no content)Symbolic AI in the 1960s was able to successfully simulate the process of high-level reasoning, including logical deduction, algebra, geometry, spatial reasoning and means-ends analysis, all of them in precise English sentences, just like the ones humans used when they reasoned.

## Challenges and Limitations

Problems with difficulties in knowledge acquisition, maintaining large knowledge bases, and brittleness in handling out-of-domain problems arose.

## Current Status

Currently, most AI researchers believe deep learning, and more likely, a synthesis of neural and symbolic approaches (neuro-symbolic AI), will be required for general intelligence.

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Swarm (simulation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(simulation)"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Repast (modeling toolkit) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Repast_(modeling_toolkit)"},{"title":"Football Manager 2011 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fm_2011"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of agent-based simulation:

## Definition

An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

## How It Works

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena.(no content)The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts". In other words, higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems. Or, macro-scale state changes emerge from micro-scale agent behaviors.

## Key Components

Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales (typically referred to as agent-granularity); (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

## Implementation

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

## History

The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

## Applications

Agent-based simulations have broad applications across multiple disciplines, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts, as well as economics, biology, and social sciences.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of the analysis:

## Paper Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Type:** Survey (literature review)

**Key Findings:**

The paper "A Review of Agent-Based Programming for Multi-Agent Systems" has been analyzed and classified as a **survey paper**, as it provides a systematic review of existing literature and discusses veteran and novel agent programming languages without proposing new techniques.

**Extracted Triples (7 total):**

1. **Intelligent agent** - Core concept of autonomous agents that perceive and reason about their environment
2. **Symbolic artificial intelligence** - The subarea of AI that frames this work
3. **Agent-oriented programming** - The main focus: programming paradigm for agent-based systems
4. **Multi-agent system** - The primary context for agent programming techniques
5. **Agent-based model** - Method for simulation and modeling multi-agent behaviors
6. **Multi-agent planning** - Key technique for coordinating multiple agents
7. **Argumentation framework** - Formal approach to multi-agent argumentation

All entities were:
- Matched with verified Wikipedia articles
- Classified with appropriate entity types (5 concepts, 2 methods)
- Marked with "uses" relation (as this is a survey paper)
- Given relevant one-sentence explanations

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!
